elements.content:
The assembly of a new secondary building unit, Zn8SiO4, and terephthalate dianion gives an exceptionally stable framework with promising photoluminescence properties.

Metal silicate, the most common inorganic material, has been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis, separation science, ion exchange, and electronic devices. Although chemically and thermally stable, these materials allow rather limited variation of chemical formulation and functionality that hinders their application. Recent advances in synthesizing metal−organic frameworks offer great potential for chemical and structural diversity through the design of the secondary building unit (SBU) and the selection of organic linkers. An example of the work is the successful use of SBU in the formation of the metal−organic framework of [Zn4O(O2C−C6H4−CO2)] n   8 that, by borrowing the metal carboxylate chemistry, extends the three-dimensional network and is stable when fully desolvated and heated to 300 °C. In comparison with metal silicate materials, however, the thermal stability of these materials still remains to be improved significantly. In our effort to seek higher thermal stability of coordination polymers, we have successfully used zinc(II) silicate and isophthalate to assemble a [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)6] n coordination polymer22 based on the synthetic strategy of the geometry matching between silicate anion and zinc ion; i.e., the zinc(II) ion in tetrahedral geometry can match well the silicate anion. The thermal property measurement shows that this coordination polymer possesses higher thermal and structural stability (500 °C), because of the highest negative charge of the silicate ion often leading to the combination of more metal ions at a network vertex, so that more organic linkers can be joined through coordination bonds. Obviously, the benefit of hybridization between metal silicate and organic ligand is a combination of the higher thermal stability of metal silicate with chemical and structural diversity of metal−organic frameworks. As a systematic investigation on the assembly rule of metallosilicate coordination polymers, in this paper, we report herein the synthesis, crystal structure, and properties of a metal−organic framework [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)6] n (1; C8H4O4 = terephthalate dianion).
elements.clean_text:
The assembly of a new secondary building unit, Zn8SiO4, and terephthalate dianion gives an exceptionally stable framework with promising photoluminescence properties.



Metal silicate, the most common inorganic material, has been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis, separation science, ion exchange, and electronic devices. Although chemically and thermally stable, these materials allow rather limited variation of chemical formulation and functionality that hinders their application. Recent advances in synthesizing metal-organic frameworks offer great potential for chemical and structural diversity through the design of the secondary building unit (SBU) and the selection of organic linkers. An example of the work is the successful use of SBU in the formation of the metal-organic framework of [Zn4O(O2C-C6H4-CO2)] n              8 that, by borrowing the metal carboxylate chemistry, extends the three-dimensional network and is stable when fully desolvated and heated to 300 °C. In comparison with metal silicate materials, however, the thermal stability of these materials still remains to be improved significantly. In our effort to seek higher thermal stability of coordination polymers, we have successfully used zinc(II) silicate and isophthalate to assemble a [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)6] n  coordination polymer22 based on the synthetic strategy of the geometry matching between silicate anion and zinc ion; i.e., the zinc(II) ion in tetrahedral geometry can match well the silicate anion. The thermal property measurement shows that this coordination polymer possesses higher thermal and structural stability (500 °C), because of the highest negative charge of the silicate ion often leading to the combination of more metal ions at a network vertex, so that more organic linkers can be joined through coordination bonds. Obviously, the benefit of hybridization between metal silicate and organic ligand is a combination of the higher thermal stability of metal silicate with chemical and structural diversity of metal-organic frameworks. As a systematic investigation on the assembly rule of metallosilicate coordination polymers, in this paper, we report herein the synthesis, crystal structure, and properties of a metal-organic framework [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)6] n  (1; C8H4O4 = terephthalate dianion).

elements.content: The synthesis is achieved by hydrothermal reaction of zinc nitrate, terephthalic acid, and sodium silicate in water at about pH 7. Single-crystal analysis25 reveals that 1 is made up of an infinite interpenetrating three-dimensional framework with a Zn8(SiO4) core as a building unit, in which the silicate anion, located in the center of the unit with each oxygen atom of the silicate anion bridging two zinc(II) atoms in a η 2 bridging mode, forms a distorted cubane-like core, with each zinc(II) atom occupying one apex of the hexahedron (Figure a). To the best of our knowledge, the Zn8(SiO4) core has the highest positive charge and the largest number of metal ions among those reported in the inorganic−organic coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis is achieved by hydrothermal reaction of zinc nitrate, terephthalic acid, and sodium silicate in water at about pH 7. Single-crystal analysis25 reveals that 1 is made up of an infinite interpenetrating three-dimensional framework with a Zn8(SiO4) core as a building unit, in which the silicate anion, located in the center of the unit with each oxygen atom of the silicate anion bridging two zinc(II) atoms in a η 2 bridging mode, forms a distorted cubane-like core, with each zinc(II) atom occupying one apex of the hexahedron (Figure a). To the best of our knowledge, the Zn8(SiO4) core has the highest positive charge and the largest number of metal ions among those reported in the inorganic-organic coordination polymers.

elements.content: (a) Perspective of the distorted cuboid core of Zn8(SiO4) in 1. (b) The 6-connected Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)12 cluster in 1. Benzene rings are simplified as straight lines.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Perspective of the distorted cuboid core of Zn8(SiO4) in 1. (b) The 6-connected Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)12 cluster in 1. Benzene rings are simplified as straight lines.

elements.content: Two zinc(II) atoms at each edge of the core are further capped by a carboxylate group of terephthalate in cis−cis mode to form a 6-connected Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)12 cluster (Figure b). Each zinc(II) atom is four-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three μ-carboxylates of terephthalate and one oxygen atom from the silicate anion to furnish a tetrahedral geometry. The bond lengths of Zn−Ocarboxylate are in the range of 1.903(4)−1.938(3) Å, compared to that found in [Zn4O(O2CPH)6] (ave 1.939 Å). The bond lengths of Zn−Osilicate range from 1.936(3) to 1.946(3) Å, slightly longer than the bond lengths of Zn−Ocarboxylate. The bond angles of Ocarboxylate−Zn−Ocarboxylate, Ocarboxylate−Zn−Osilicate, and O−Si−O in the silicate anion are in the ranges of 103.63(2)−111.00(16)°, 103.31(14)−122.65(15)°, and 107.73(14)−111.8(2)°, respectively, indicating that the silicate anion matches well the ZnO4 geometry.
elements.clean_text: Two zinc(II) atoms at each edge of the core are further capped by a carboxylate group of terephthalate in cis-cis mode to form a 6-connected Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)12 cluster (Figure b). Each zinc(II) atom is four-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three μ-carboxylates of terephthalate and one oxygen atom from the silicate anion to furnish a tetrahedral geometry. The bond lengths of Zn-Ocarboxylate are in the range of 1.903(4)-1.938(3) Å, compared to that found in [Zn4O(O2CPH)6] (ave 1.939 Å). The bond lengths of Zn-Osilicate range  from 1.936(3) to 1.946(3) Å, slightly longer than the bond lengths of Zn-Ocarboxylate. The bond angles of Ocarboxylate-Zn-Ocarboxylate, Ocarboxylate-Zn-Osilicate, and O-Si-O in the silicate anion are in the ranges of 103.63(2)-111.00(16)°, 103.31(14)-122.65(15)°, and 107.73(14)-111.8(2)°, respectively, indicating that the silicate anion matches well the ZnO4 geometry.

elements.content: The most striking feature in 1 is the 6 connection of the distorted cuboid SBU, which, joined by 12 terephthalates, gives a three-dimensional structure bearing two identical interpenetrating networks (Figure ). To explore how the SBU influences the interpenetrating network, we also calculate the n value, a function of diameter of spherical SBU d and length of linker l (d = 8.82 Å and l = 5.78 Å) in 1. The n value near 2 indicates that 1 has only two interpenetrating networks and consists well with the d ln v plot that relates to n, d, and l in the cubic system reported by Yaghi and co-workers. Despite 1 being the interpenetrated network, the synthesis of the open framework of metallosilicate-containing compounds is expected if reaction conditions are optimized.
elements.clean_text: The most striking feature in 1 is the 6 connection of the distorted cuboid SBU, which, joined by 12 terephthalates, gives a three-dimensional structure bearing two identical interpenetrating networks (Figure ). To explore how the SBU influences the interpenetrating network, we also calculate the n value, a function of diameter of spherical SBU d and length of linker l (d = 8.82 Å and l = 5.78 Å) in 1. The n value near 2 indicates that 1 has only two interpenetrating networks and consists well with the d ln v plot that relates to n, d, and l in the cubic system reported by Yaghi and co-workers. Despite 1 being the interpenetrated network, the synthesis of the open framework of metallosilicate-containing compounds is expected if reaction conditions are optimized.

elements.content: (a) Interpenetrating networks of1. (b) ORTEP (ellipsoids at 50% probability; hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity) view of one set of the networks in 1 along the b axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Interpenetrating networks of1. (b) ORTEP (ellipsoids at 50% probability; hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity) view of one set of the networks in 1 along the b axis.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 1 has exceptional thermal stability. The material has no weight loss before 520 °C in nitrogen, indicating that 1 is stable as high as 520 °C, which is significantly higher than that of the diamondoid three-dimensional framework of bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}zinc (430 °C). Especially, 1 even exhibits high chemical stability in air. Further TGA in air shows that the material has no weight loss below 500 °C. The strongly endothermic peak appears at 570 °C, which is even higher than two highly thermally robust metal coordination polymers in a nitrogen atmosphere. Such a chemical stability has never been reported in inorganic−organic hybrid materials. The higher stability of 1 is mainly a result of the combination of more metal ions at a network vertex joined by more organic linkers through coordination bonds.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 1 has exceptional thermal stability. The material has no weight loss before 520 °C in nitrogen, indicating that 1 is stable as high as 520 °C, which is significantly higher than that of the diamondoid three-dimensional framework of bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}zinc (430 °C). Especially, 1 even exhibits high chemical stability  in air. Further TGA in air shows that the material has no weight loss below 500 °C. The strongly endothermic peak appears at 570 °C, which is even higher than two highly thermally robust metal coordination polymers in a nitrogen atmosphere. Such a chemical stability has never been reported in inorganic-organic hybrid materials. The higher stability of 1 is mainly a result of the combination of more metal ions at a network vertex joined by more organic linkers through coordination bonds.

elements.content: In solid state, 1 exhibits strong fluorescence and weak phosphorescence. The fluorescence emission occurs at 386 nm upon photoexcitation at 315 nm, which may be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transfer. Except that the fluorescence intensity of 1 is much stronger than that of the ligand, the emission wavelength of fluorescence in 1 is very similar to that of the ligand (386 nm), indicating that the stronger fluorescence of 1 is mainly attributed to the coordination of the zinc(II) atom enhancing rigidity of the terephthalato group. 1 also emits green phosphorescence at 506 nm upon photoexcitation at 338 nm with a lifetime of 6.78 ms, which could be a reflection of the rigid three-dimensional structure of the polymer. Because 1 is highly thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents, it can be a good candidate for diode devices.
elements.clean_text: In solid state, 1 exhibits strong fluorescence and weak phosphorescence. The fluorescence emission occurs at 386 nm upon photoexcitation at 315 nm, which may be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transfer. Except that the fluorescence intensity of 1 is much stronger than that of the ligand, the emission wavelength of fluorescence in 1 is very similar to that of the ligand (386 nm), indicating that the stronger fluorescence of 1 is mainly attributed to the coordination of the zinc(II) atom enhancing rigidity of the terephthalato group. 1 also emits green phosphorescence at 506 nm upon photoexcitation at 338 nm with a lifetime of 6.78 ms, which could be a reflection of the rigid three-dimensional structure of the polymer. Because 1 is highly thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents, it can be a good candidate for diode devices.

elements.content: The synthesis of the hybrid material assembled from metal silicate and organic ligand has provided a new metal−organic framework with exceptional thermal and chemical stability and promising photoelectronic properties. It was clear that the structure of 1 is much different from that of [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)6] n (C8H4O4 = isophthalate), indicating that a different topology of the coordination polymer is obtained when different ligands are applied. Given the extremely rich structures of silicate ions and various combinations of metal ions and ligands, a large field of new and exciting materials with unique structures and properties is promising.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis of the hybrid material assembled from metal silicate and organic ligand has provided a new metal-organic framework with exceptional thermal and chemical stability and promising photoelectronic properties. It was clear that the structure of 1 is much different from that of [Zn8(SiO4)(C8H4O4)6] n  (C8H4O4 = isophthalate), indicating that a different topology of the coordination polymer is obtained when different ligands are applied. Given the extremely rich structures of silicate ions and various combinations of metal ions and ligands, a large field of new and exciting materials with unique structures and properties is promising.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic file in CIF format (CCDC-174992; in zip-compressed format because of the existence of large files) and thermogravimetric analysis and photoluminescence data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that 1 has exceptional thermal stability. The material has no weight loss before 520 °C in nitrogen, indicating that 1 is stable as high as 520 °C, which is significantly higher than that of the diamondoid three-dimensional framework of bis{4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato}zinc (430 °C). Especially, 1 even exhibits high chemical stability in air. Further TGA in air shows that the material has no weight loss below 500 °C. The strongly endothermic peak appears at 570 °C, which is even higher than two highly thermally robust metal coordination polymers in a nitrogen atmosphere. Such a chemical stability has never been reported in inorganic−organic hybrid materials. The higher stability of 1 is mainly a result of the combination of more metal ions at a network vertex joined by more organic linkers through coordination bonds.

metadata.title:
An Exceptionally Stable Metal−Organic
Framework Constructed from the Zn8(SiO4)
Core
